Award.AwardTitle: The Minerals, Metals & Materials Society (TMS) Annual Meeting: National Science Foundation Grant Proposal Writing Workshop; Nashville, Tennessee; 14-18 February 2016

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
This award will provide travel funds for participants in the NSF Grant Proposal Writing Workshop at the 2016 Annual Meeting of the Minerals, Metals and Materials Society (TMS) in Nashville, Tennessee. The workshop will be held the first day of the Annual Meeting, 14 February 2016. Current and former NSF Program Officers will provide an overview of the proposal review process.

The award will support workshop registration and travel for approximately 10 participants in the workshop. The registration and travel support for this workshop will be prioritized for researchers from underrepresented groups as well as early career researchers to help encourage greater participation by these groups in the minerals, metals and materials fields. Ultimately, the goal of the workshop is to help foster future generations of materials scientists and engineers by further increasing PIs' preparedness in the proposal development and submission process.

POR.DRECONTENT:
To improve the readiness of early career investigators and ensure high quality proposal submissions to the National Science Foundation (NSF) from all researchers, The Minerals, Metals & Materials Society (TMS) held a NSF Grant Proposal Writing Workshop during the society’s Annual Meeting and Exhibition in Nashville, Tennessee on February 14, 2016 (Web: http://www.tms.org/meetings/annual-16/AM16pd_NSF.aspx). The half-day workshop was developed and led by two individuals with experience as Program Directors at NSF and was intended to create a unique professional development opportunity where scientists and engineers could get questions answered and freely discuss the proposal submission process in a low-pressure environment.

Registration and travel support for this event enabled 10 early career investigators to attend the workshop. Support was provided to individuals who submitted a request to participate. Since the workshop was designed specifically for early career investigators, it covered a range of topics from basic grant writing skills to more advanced tips on navigating funding opportunities and finding the right home for one’s research. A breakout session also enabled small groups to assess sample project summaries and talk about the fundamental elements of successful grant proposals. Since the audience was primarily comprised of materials scientists and engineers, related opportunities were also presented by the workshop instructors.

Based on the participants’ feedback, the workshop was successful in achieving its aim of better preparing early career investigators for submitting high quality proposals to NSF.
